functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: Who were the Nobel Laureates in Literature from 2010 to 2015, and what are the titles of their most famous works?

article_title: List of Nobel laureates in Literature

msg.content:
<document>
<title>List of Nobel laureates in Literature</title>
<fragment>
123. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2015". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 21 September 2015. Retrieved 8 October 2015.
124. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2016" (PDF). Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original (PDF) on 2017-09-20. Retrieved 13 October 2016.
125. **^** "The Nobel Prize in Literature 2017 – Press Release". Nobel Prize. Archived from the original on 5 October 2017. Retrieved 5 October 2017.
126. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2018". Nobel Foundation. Retrieved 2019-10-10.
127. **^** "The Nobel Prize in Literature 2019". *NobelPrize.org*. Retrieved 2019-10-10.
128. **^** "The Nobel Prize in Literature 2020". *NobelPrize.org*. Retrieved 8 October 2020.
129. **^** "The Nobel Prize in Literature 2021". *NobelPrize.org*. Retrieved 7 October 2021.
130. **^** "The Nobel Prize in Literature 2022". *NobelPrize.org*. Retrieved 6 October 2022.
131. **^** The Nobel Prize in Literature 2023 nobelprize.org

</fragment>
<fragment>
116. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2008". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 12 October 2008. Retrieved 14 October 2008.
117. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2009". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 11 October 2009. Retrieved 8 October 2009.
118. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2010". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 9 October 2010. Retrieved 7 October 2010.
119. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2011". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 7 October 2011. Retrieved 6 October 2011.
120. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2012". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 10 October 2012. Retrieved 11 October 2012.
121. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2013". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 10 October 2013. Retrieved 27 January 2013.
122. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2014". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 31 December 2014. Retrieved 24 December 2014.

</fragment>
<fragment>
108. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2000". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-17. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
109. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2001". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2016-02-01. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
110. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2002". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-21. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
111. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2003". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-19. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
112. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2004". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-21. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
113. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2005". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-17. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
114. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2006". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-16. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
115. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 2007". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-16. Retrieved 2008-10-17.

</fragment>
<fragment>

Seventeen women have been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature, the second highest number of any of the Nobel Prizes behind the Nobel Peace Prize.[11][12] There have been four instances in which the award was given to two people (1904, 1917, 1966, 1974). There have been seven years in which the Nobel Prize in Literature was not awarded (1914, 1918, 1935, 1940–1943). There have been three years for which the Nobel Prize in Literature was delayed one year: the prizes for 1915,[13] 1949[14] and 2018[15][16][6] were each awarded together with that of the following year in October of the following year. As of 2022, there have been 29 English-speaking laureates of the Nobel Prize in Literature, followed by French with 16 laureates and German with 14 laureates. France has the highest number of Nobel laureates.




## Laureates[edit]


* 1901
* 1910
* 1920
* 1930
* 1940
* 1950
* 1960
* 1970
* 1980
* 1990
* 2000
* 2010
* 2020




</fragment>
<fragment>
| * v
* t
* e
Laureates of the Nobel Prize in Literature
 |
| --- |
| 1901–1920 | * 1901: Sully Prudhomme
* 1902: Theodor Mommsen
* 1903: Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson
* 1904: Frédéric Mistral / José Echegaray
* 1905: Henryk Sienkiewicz
* 1906: Giosuè Carducci
* 1907: Rudyard Kipling
* 1908: Rudolf Eucken
* 1909: Selma Lagerlöf
* 1910: Paul Heyse
* 1911: Maurice Maeterlinck
* 1912: Gerhart Hauptmann
* 1913: Rabindranath Tagore
* 1914
* 1915: Romain Rolland
* 1916: Verner von Heidenstam
* 1917: Karl Gjellerup / Henrik Pontoppidan
* 1918
* 1919: Carl Spitteler
* 1920: Knut Hamsun
 |
| 1921–1940 | * 1921: Anatole France
* 1922: Jacinto Benavente
* 1923: W. B. Yeats
* 1924: Władysław Reymont
* 1925: George Bernard Shaw
* 1926: Grazia Deledda
* 1927: Henri Bergson
* 1928: Sigrid Undset
* 1929: Thomas Mann
* 1930: Sinclair Lewis
* 1931: Erik Axel Karlfeldt (*posthumously*)
* 1932: John Galsworthy
* 1933: Ivan Bunin
* 1934: Luigi Pirandello
* 1935
* 1936: Eugene O'Neill
* 1937: Roger Martin du Gard
* 1938: Pearl S. Buck

</fragment>
<fragment>
14. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Nobel Prize in Literature 1949". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-19. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
15. **^** "2018 Nobel Prize In Literature Is A Casualty Of Sex-Abuse Scandal". *NPR.org*. NPR. Archived from the original on 11 November 2018. Retrieved 1 November 2018.
16. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature awarded to Olga Tokarczuk and Peter Handke". *The Independent*. 10 October 2019. Retrieved 10 October 2019.
17. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 1901". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-21. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
18. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 1902". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-11. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
19. **^** "Nobel Prize in Literature 1903". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-11. Retrieved 2008-10-17.
20. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Nobel Prize in Literature 1904". Nobel Foundation. Archived from the original on 2008-10-11. Retrieved 2008-10-17.

</fragment>
<fragment>

1Rabindranath Tagore (Nobel Prize in Literature 1913) wrote in Bengali and English, Samuel Beckett (Nobel Prize in Literature 1969) wrote in French and English and Joseph Brodsky (Nobel Prize in Literature 1987) wrote poetry in Russian and prose in English. These three Nobel laureates have been sorted under Bengali, French and Russian, respectively.[132]


2Karl Adolph Gjellerup (Nobel Prize in Literature 1917) wrote in Danish and German.



## Nobel laureates by sex[edit]


The 120 Nobel laureates in literature from 1901 to 2023 were from the following sexes:





| **Decade** | **Male** | **Female** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1900–1909
 | 9
 | 1
 |
| 1910–1919
 | 9
 | 0
 |
| 1920–1929
 | 8
 | 2
 |
| 1930–1939
 | 8
 | 1
 |
| 1940–1949
 | 5
 | 1
 |
| 1950–1959
 | 10
 | 0
 |
| 1960–1969
 | 10
 | 1
 |
| 1970–1979
 | 11
 | 0
 |
| 1980–1989
 | 10
 | 0
 |
| 1990–1999
 | 7
 | 3
 |
| 2000–2009
 | 7
 | 3
 |
| 2010–2019
 | 7
 | 3
 |
| 2020–2029
 | 2
 | 2
 |
| **Total** | 103
 | 17
 |

msg.name: search

msg.content:
Here are the Nobel Laureates in Literature from 2010 to 2015 along with the titles of their most famous works:

1. **2010: Mario Vargas Llosa**
   - **Famous Work:** "The Time of the Hero" (La ciudad y los perros)

2. **2011: Tomas Tranströmer**
   - **Famous Work:** "Baltics" (Östersjöar)

3. **2012: Mo Yan**
   - **Famous Work:** "Red Sorghum" (红高粱家族)

4. **2013: Alice Munro**
   - **Famous Work:** "Dear Life"

5. **2014: Patrick Modiano**
   - **Famous Work:** "Missing Person" (Rue des Boutiques Obscures)

6. **2015: Svetlana Alexievich**
   - **Famous Work:** "Voices from Chernobyl" (Чернобыльская молитва)

These authors were recognized for their significant contributions to literature, each bringing unique perspectives and styles to the literary world.

These authors were recognized for their significant contributions to literature, each bringing unique perspectives and styles to the literary world.
